author: Hannah Bartlett
title: Tourist jumps into sea to save whale pod from stranding
text:
Tourist jumps into sea to save whale pod from stranding HANNAH BARTLETT Last updated 12:48, February 14 2017 MARTIN DE RUYTER/FAIRFAX NZ 
DOC is warning that dead whales are expected to keep washing up on beaches around Golden Bay. 
A German tourist who jumped off his bike and waded into the sea to stop whales from stranding deserves a beer, the Department of Conservation (DOC) says. 
DOC Golden Bay Operations manager Andrew Lamason has praised the efforts of the man, and that of a family, who helped prevent another restranding near Taupata Point. 
A pod of up to 200 whales had been milling off the coast near Farewell Spit on Monday afternoon, following a mass stranding of more than 400 whales over the weekend. 
Andrew Lamason said one of his DOC rangers had been made aware of the holiday-maker's heroic actions by someone who saw the rescue. 
READ MORE: * Why is saving the whales so important to New Zealanders? 
"There was a German guy riding his bike who just jumped straight in there and a family driving past and they managed to get about six or seven of these whales that were coming right up into the strand zone, turn them around, gave them a bit of slap and sent them back out to sea," Lamason said. 
"If you find out who they are, let me know and I'll buy them a beer because they saved us a huge amount of work, I think." 
Do you know the tourist who jumped off his bike to save the whales? Email 
Lamason said one of the tourists didn't even take off his helmet before running into the water. 
"It was really cool," he said. 
A release from DOC this morning brought welcome news that there had been no further restrandings or Monday night or Tuesday morning. 
"We're just fully into the clean-up and recovery mode now," Lamason said. 
"There's a dead [whale] that's washed up on Tata Beach so we're pulling that off at high tide. We're putting out the message to people to say there will be quite a few of these things floating around in the bay, and they'll be turning up on beaches." 
He said if people came across whale carcasses they should contact DOC. 
"I wouldn't get too close to them. The smell is terrible and I wouldn't go touching them that's for sure. When we're working with them we've got gloves on, we've got the full white suits and face shields," he said. 
Lamason also warned dog-owners walking along the beach that whale meat could make dogs very sick so they should be wary of letting dogs run off where they might come across a carcass. 
He said the full cost of the whale rescue and recovery was not yet known. 
"The total cost will not be known until all the carcasses that are still at sea have stopped turning up on beaches," Lamason said. 
"That can often be more expensive than dealing with all the whales one time on Farewell Spit." 
The dead whales on Farewell Spit were moved on Monday with a digger to dunes in an area of the nature reserve that is not open to public walking access. - Stuff
